title: 110_hr5962
content: The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" is a temporary deduction for certain mortgage counseling under section 224 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" allows individuals to deduct up to $500 for qualified mortgage counseling provided by an organization accredited by the Federal Housing Administration before obtaining a loan. The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" allows a deduction for mortgage counseling related to loans secured by the taxpayer's principal residence. The deduction is not allowed for amounts paid after December 31, 2012. The table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" is amended by redesignating section 224 as section 225. SEC. 225 introduces a temporary deduction for upside-down mortgages starting after December 31, 2007. The deduction allows individuals to deduct 20 percent of the excess acquisition indebtedness on their principal residence over its valuation for real property tax assessments, limited to $5,000 per year. The deduction for upside down mortgages allows individuals to deduct 20 percent of excess acquisition indebtedness on their principal residence, capped at $5,000 per year. Material misstatements in obtaining the indebtedness will disqualify the deduction, and it is not allowed for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2009. The deduction for upside down mortgages allows individuals to deduct excess acquisition indebtedness on their principal residence, capped at $5,000 per year. Material misstatements will disqualify the deduction, and it is not allowed for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2009. Amendment to section 224 allows for this deduction. The amendment allows for a deduction for upside down mortgages, capped at $5,000 per year, with material misstatements disqualifying the deduction. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. Additionally, a temporary credit for certain home purchases is introduced under section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment introduces a temporary credit for certain home purchases under section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code. For individuals purchasing a qualified principal residence, a credit is allowed against the tax imposed, equal to 10% of the purchase price or $7,500 ($9,000 in high-cost areas). The credit for home purchases must be divided equally over two taxable years starting from the year of purchase. Limitations include purchases made after the enactment date but before 12 months after, and a cap based on modified adjusted gross income. The credit for home purchases is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with a threshold of $70,000 ($140,000 for joint returns). The credit for home purchases is limited by the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, which is the adjusted gross income plus any excluded amounts under specific sections. The credit cannot exceed the excess of $20,000 in taxable years where section 26(a)(2) does not apply. The credit for home purchases is limited by the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The credit cannot exceed the excess of the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, over the sum of the credits allowable for the taxable year. If a credit is allowed for the purchase of a qualified principal residence, it is one-time only for an individual and their spouse. The credit for home purchases is limited by the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. If a credit is allowed for the purchase of a qualified principal residence, it is one-time only for an individual and their spouse. No credit shall be allowed for the purchase of any other qualified principal residence by the same individual or spouse. Additionally, no credit shall be allowed if a credit has been previously claimed by any of the individuals involved in a joint purchase. The term 'qualified principal residence' refers to a residence purchased to be the principal residence of the buyer, with no double benefit allowed if a credit is claimed under another section. In the event of disposing or not occupying a qualified principal residence within 24 months of purchase, the remaining portion of the credit allowed will be disallowed. In cases where a taxpayer disposes of or fails to occupy a qualified principal residence within 24 months of purchase, the remaining portion of the credit allowed will be disallowed. Special rules apply for joint purchases, such as married individuals filing separately or unmarried individuals. If unmarried individuals purchase a qualified principal residence, the credit allowed shall be allocated among them, not exceeding $7,000. Rules similar to section 1400C(e) apply for purchase and purchase price. The enactment date of this section applies, along with reporting requirements similar to section 1400C(f). A basis adjustment is made if a credit is allowed for a residence purchase. Conforming amendments include adding section 25E to the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include section 25E, along with other amendments to sections 25B, 25D, 26, and 904. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include section 25E, along with amendments to sections 25B, 25D, and 26. Additionally, section 1400C(d)(2) is amended by adding references to section 25E. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new item, section 25E, following amendments to sections 25B, 25D, and 26. Section 25E provides a credit for certain home purchases, with amendments applying to purchases in taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment is subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Additionally, a temporary additional standard deduction for real property taxes is introduced for nonitemizers. In 2008 and 2009, a real property tax deduction is added to the standard deduction in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This deduction applies to taxable years beginning in 2008 or 2009. The real property tax deduction is limited to $500 ($1,000 for joint returns) for eligible State and local real property taxes paid or accrued by the taxpayer during the taxable year. Eligible taxes are defined as State and local real property taxes according to section 164. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 6 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude unemployment compensation from gross income for individuals in 2008 and 2009. This change applies to amounts received after December 31, 2007.
